pageContext.claim: “Well, we're down 17 percent from last year. And a lot of its doctors prescribing too much and a lot of things happening but opioid's a big problem.”
pageContext.analysis: A White House spokesman told CNN that Trump was referring to a 17 percent decline in monthly opioid prescriptions since Trump took office. "However, a large reason opioid prescribing has dropped is because the CDC issued opioid prescribing guidelines in early 2016 , which resulted both in doctors prescribing fewer opioids as well as insurers providing less coverage for opioids. And while opioid prescriptions have dropped during Trump's term, fentanyl-related overdose deaths continued to rise, according to CDC data," CNN reported.
